ANNUAL BUDGET STATEMENT


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [25th February 2000],

    "That Parliament approves the financial policy of the Government for the financial year 1st April, 2000 to 31st March, 2001." - [Minister for Finance].

    Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam (Non-Constituency Member): Sir, do we have a quorum here?

    Mr Speaker: Are you asking for a quorum?

    Mr Jeyaretnam: I thought a quorum is 20 Members or something. I am wondering whether we have a quorum.

    Mr Speaker: There is a process for finding out. If you are not insisting on that process, I propose to proceed.

    Question again proposed.

    The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Zainul Abidin Rasheed): Mr Speaker Sir, thank you for allowing me to participate in the debate on the Budget Statement. I rise in support of the motion in the name of the Minister for Finance, Dr Richard Hu.

    Sir, much has already been said on how to make our economy strong and competitive. After all, the Budget is about the economics of governing Singapore.

    While Mr Inderjit Singh's magic of doing business through the Internet is fascinating, I am glad that Mr Sinnakaruppan has reminded us of the concerns about the digital divide.

    It is in this context that I find Dr Hu ending his remarks on the Budget Statement with a sober reminder about the importance of social cohesion as interesting, if not telling. I quote:

    "Most important of all, we have to work on preserving our social cohesion, without which we will be much weaker as a nation in weathering a future crisis."

Perhaps a coincidence, or perhaps to buttress the point, the Straits Times released, a day after Budget Day, survey

Column: 1299

results on ethnic relations which say a lot about our vulnerabilities as a multi-racial and multi-religious society.

    No, Sir, I would not bore you with more rhetorics about why we must not get complacent about race relations and multi-racial harmony, but suffice to say that those survey findings should serve as a wake up call for us that all is not well when it comes to our social cohesion.

    Yes, Sir, I can see the progress we have made. But there is still a lot of ground to be covered before we can really say that we are truly race and colour blind. The survey results proved this.

    Perhaps the survey results could have been more positive if it were carried out in better times, when Singapore-Malaysia relations were warmer. The letter by a Malaysian Malay, Malik Tahir, published in the Straits Times, looking at Malaysia-Singapore relations from the point of view of the so-called abang-adik, or big brother and small brother, and ethnic Malay-Chinese angle, would not help. So with the May 1997 anti-Chinese riots in Indonesia and the off and on Christian-Muslim killings in Maluku.

    Thus, all the more we need to continue to work hard at improving race relations in Singapore. Whether it is a question of promoting understanding and even more difficult, to build better trust, something that will take a longer time to achieve, we have to soldier on.

    Allow me to share with you a conversation I had with my son, an officer in the army. He was of course appalled at the survey results. He was saddened that about 60% believed that there was a need to check the background of a Malay officer before putting him in an important position in the SAF. He protested pointedly - I quote: "Put yourself in the position where you are putting your best foot forward, you are all hearts and soul to serve the SAF and Singapore, how would you feel about such survey findings?" - when responding to the survey finding about the question of whether to trust the

Column: 1300

Malays in times of war with a Malay/Muslim country.

    He comforted himself by saying that perhaps the survey could be seen academically. "What matters", he said, "are practical situations." He was confident that his men, whom he served NS with, would feel differently. Having trained and served together under NS would have made that difference. He feels that whatever the feelings shown in the survey, primordial or otherwise, we must continue to develop better bonding and better trust.

    Sir, I share that sentiment. We have no choice. When we believe in our Singapore, we have to soldier on with better bonding. We must continue to work hard at nurturing better understanding and trust. That may sound rhetorical, but there is no other way. We all know, of course, that slogans and speeches are not enough. Each one of us has got the responsibility and a role to play. Let us spread the gospel of harmonious living as wide as possible.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, in developing Singapore, Dr Hu said in his Budget Speech that the challenge is for us "to differentiate ourselves by finding creative ways to add value to our infrastructure."

    Dr Hu cited the development of Jurong Island as one example of that creativity. He said, "Amalgamated from seven offshore islands, Jurong Island is to become a world-class integrated chemical hub, the first of its kind in the region." Such is also our challenge for social cohesion. Let us "amalgamate" our different races together, wherever possible, into one main Singapore race. There is definitely more room for better racial and social chemistry.

    Dr Hu went on to say that Jurong Island, "Through clustering and sharing of common facilities, it will generate synergistic linkages across a wide spectrum of petrochemical industries." He said, "For example, the provision of centralised logistics and common corridors for material flows will significantly reduce feedstock transportation and handling cost."

Column: 1301



    We should try to transplant those same concepts in forging multi-racial harmony. We will need to see a greater sharing of common efforts that will not only generate synergy but also open new highways of opportunities for the different ethnic groups to integrate. This way, we will be able to reduce the constant heartaches that every so often show their ugly heads. The political cost of racial discord could also be avoided.

    In the same vein of the formation of JurongIsland.com, mentioned by Dr Hu in his Budget Statement, let us build HarmonyIsland.com, either under the Prime Minister's Office or the Ministry of Community Development, to help us open a new corridor to a more harmonious living in our Singapore. Let this HarmonyIsland.com be far more meaningful than the commercial Orchard.com, for it will encompass the spirit of Chinatown.com, Geylang.com, LittleIndia.com and even Katong.com. And, in short, making the true spirit of multi-racial Singapore come to life through the magic of Internet and IT.

    We should apply the same zeal and creativity that we often exercise for our economic achievements to our effort at ensuring racial and religious harmony.

    The Malay/Muslim community recognises the dangers of a possible digital divide. They have embarked on a KBE movement launched by the Prime Minister last December to help the community equip itself with the right skills, in order to play its part in competitive and global Singapore. Obviously, this is just a beginning, a modest start. More will have to be done.

    The Malay/Muslim organisations will have to speed up its momentum in this area, work in tandem with national programmes and Government agencies to keep abreast with the demands of the digital race. Government Ministries and agencies too should help complement and supplement the efforts by the Malay/Muslim community towards this end.

    While the community continues to work hard to tackle its lingering problems in

Column: 1302

education and socio-economic realms, neither the community nor Singapore can afford another divide to emerge from the digital era.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I trust Dr Hu will say "yes" to HarmonyIsland.com, to help promote better racial harmony in Singapore and alleviate the potential divide.

    Sir, I support the motion.

    Mr Tay Beng Chuan (Nominated Member)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, on behalf of the business community in Singapore, I would like to thank the Government for its able leadership in strongly advocating the tripartism of the labour, management and the Government to adopt the cost-cutting package to deal with the Asian financial crisis, enabling Singapore's economy to recover steadily last year and achieving a 5.4% growth for the whole year.

    Sir, after having gone through this financial crisis, I deeply appreciate the spiritual strength of tripartism of labour, management and the Government which is a pre-requisite for Singapore's economy to develop and remain stable in the face of chaos. We must carry forward this spirit of tripartism at all costs. In view of this, I must present for discussion in this House the views of the business community on the way the Government dealt with the cost-cutting package and the huge budget surplus achieved last year, with the hope that the Government would continue to conform to the wishes of the people and adopt appropriate measures to enhance the business community's confidence in the labour-management-Government tripartite strategy.

    Sir, because of the economic recovery in FY 1999, we were able to turn deficits into surplus, enabling most workers to retain their jobs and many enterprises to survive. It can be said to be happiness all round. However, many Singaporeans told me that the Government could be said to be the biggest winner in the financial bumper harvest. According to the Finance Minister, last year's revenue from COEs and income tax was much more than

Column: 1303

predicted. On the other hand, tender prices for the Government's development projects were substantially lower. At the same time, the Government had also shelved some of the less important development plans, thereby saving some hefty sums of expenditure for the Government. As such, not only has the Government not injected the $5.1 billion as promised into the economy, but it received a bumper surplus of $3.2 billion instead.

    From the business community's point of view, the surplus obtained by the Government on this occasion could not help but give people the feeling of "robbing Peter to pay Paul". Those in the construction industry are particularly unhappy. Because of the serious impact of the financial crisis, coupled with intense competition, building contractors had to resort to bidding below cost for the limited contracts offered by the Government, in order to survive and to retain their staff and workers, much to the benefit of the Government.

    The big and small building contractors in Singapore could be said to be in a sorry plight in the process of dealing with the impact of the financial storm. They had not only to try and save the industry which seemed unable to recover after a setback, through self-sacrifice, but also to try their best to keep the rice-bowls of their employees. This is something that warrants our attention. Moreover, the construction industry has all along been an important link in our economy, and cannot be neglected. As such, I would urge the Government to bring forward as soon as possible the development projects which it had shelved so that the construction industry can restore its vitality earlier and catch up with the other sectors of our economy on the road to recovery.

    Sir, in actual fact, the difference between the $3.2 billion FY 1999 budget surplus achieved and the $5.1 billion budget deficit predicted was really tremendous. This is incredible! Many Singaporeans could not help asking: Has the

Column: 1304

Government been over cautious in formulating and implementing the cost-cutting package introduced by the Government to help the people tide over the financial crisis? Or was it because the Government had been half-hearted in its efforts, resulting in it being unable to produce better and more comprehensive results? Perhaps the Government was not practising what it preached when it advocated the tripartism of labour, management and Government. Furthermore, is the Government planning to conduct a full review on the manner in which it formulates the annual Budget to avoid a repetition of such a huge gap in the estimates which sends the wrong signal to the business community and causes the business community to lose faith in the Government's economic strategies?

    Sir, generally, enterprises must have rich financial resources to survive, develop and undertake risks involved with exploiting innovative business. At this time when our economy has just recovered from the recession and the situation of our neighbouring economies is still not certain, most enterprises would need to accumulate more reserves from their operating surpluses for contingency use, just like any government. However, it is regrettable that our Government seems to be in a great hurry to withdraw the 10% rebate on corporate tax from this year's Budget. At the same time, the property tax rebate on industrial properties is reduced from 55% to 25%. Although the Government announced a reduction of 0.5 percentage point in the corporate tax rate to 25.5%, this will not take effect until next year. Generally, the people will find such lack of generosity difficult to accept. No wonder some businessmen are now asking: "Is the Government sincere in wanting to share the happiness and bitterness with the business community? Why is the Government not sharing the fruits of the economic recovery with them in line with the spirit of tripartism?"

    Sir, as we are strongly encouraging our businessmen to be adventurous in opening up new markets and developing new products, we should appreciate that these businessmen are in dire need of more surpluses and capital to back them up in

Column: 1305

order to accept the challenges. As such, I hope that the Government would further reduce more taxes to enable our enterprises to enhance their competitiveness, and strive for more operating surpluses and accumulate enough capital to develop their business. In this respect, I would urge the Government to grant our local enterprises, particularly the newly established SMEs, special tax concessions, such as allowing them reliefs from their taxable income, similar to the personal reliefs in individual income tax. Alternatively, the SMEs could be allowed to pay their income tax on a progressive scale to alleviate their tax burden.

    Sir, I commend the Government for allocating funds to the Medifund, the ElderCare Fund, and the top-up of $250 to the ordinary accounts of the CPF members, so that our people would get to share as much as $685 million from the budget surplus of YA1999. However, compared to the $3.2 billion surplus, this amount is still relatively small. Perhaps, the Government would consider allocating some funds from the surplus to finance the various industrial and commercial organisations so that they could conduct various skills upgrading activities and training programmes for workers in the various trades and industries.

    Sir, we notice that in the new fiscal year, the Government will be allocating $3.3 billion to the public service for manpower expenditure, an increase of as high as 10.8%. Yet, the Government is forecasting an economic growth of only 4.5% to 6.5% for this year. As we all know, any increase in salaries in the public sector would bring about a vicious cycle in the other sectors of the economy, resulting in an unconstrained escalation in wage cost in Singapore. Now, the private sector is trying to exercise wage restraint to cut down business cost, but the public sector persists in its argument of having to attract talents and keeps on making substantial upward adjustments to wages. Is this not contrary to the cooperative spirit of our tripartism? As such, I would urge the Government to exercise extreme caution whenever it raises the salaries in the public sector, to avoid accelerated

Column: 1306

escalation in business cost and the burden on the taxpayers.

    Sir, the Budget for the new century is of utmost importance to our development. It is the motivating force to move us into the knowledge-based economy. I am very pleased with the Government for all its efforts in this aspect. However, we must always take note that in this globalised economy and era of information technology, we are bound to face some rapidly changing situations. I hope that the Government will continue with its style of adopting appropriately to changes and conforming to the wishes of the people. Whenever necessary, the Government should be resolute in making prompt decisions and adopt suitable measures to lead the people in the spirit of our tripatism to counter the challenges of the new century and move into the knowledge-based economy for our future development.

    Dr Ong Chit Chung (Bukit Timah): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for allowing me to join in the debate.

    First and foremost, Sir, we must thank and congratulate our Government for its outstanding management and leadership in pulling Singapore out of its worst economic crisis that hit this region.

    No one, Sir, can deny that the Government has done well indeed for the people and for the country. In comparison with other governments, this Government stands up and stands tall, as one with the vision, the courage and the determination to see us through to the promised land, and to bring us to new heights in the new economy.

    Nevertheless, we were surprised the other day to hear from the Minister for Finance that for the last financial year, instead of the projected $5 billion deficit, the Government has turned in an estimated $3.2 billion surplus. Any surplus is good and most welcome. But the question in our mind is: had the Government been overly cautious and extraordinarily conservative in holding back expenditures? Had the Government not held back so much and released more funds into the economy, would there not have been a

Column: 1307

greater multiplier impact and faster recovery of the economy?

    Now the Government has quickly cut and reduced some of the rebates, and increased significantly, for example, the development charges for properties. Are these actions too drastic and too soon? Will they lead to other Government departments and agencies raising their charges quickly?

    The pendulum must not swing the other way too quickly, otherwise business costs will rise sharply, and that will hurt the competitiveness of our economy and our own country. We should give more time for companies to restructure and consolidate. Do not forget, ultimately, we have to compete against other regional economies, like Hong Kong, Taiwan and Thailand.

    Overall, I am glad that the Government is taking good care of the man-in-the-street, with rental rebates, rebates for S&C charges and utilities rebates, and the CPF top-up scheme. This shows that the Government has a heart for our heartlanders, and appreciates the sacrifices made by the people in taking pay and CPF cuts in difficult times.

    Sir, in this budget, we are spending the lion's share on education. This is the right move. People are our precious, and only resources, more so in the knowledge-based economy, the very foundation of our future.

    While we invest so much on education, will it not be wise for us to do a strategic review of education, a stock-taking and seeking new directions in the new economy, in the new world of the Internet, wired together in one global village? I ask this as it is clear that the pace of change has quickened, and the momentum may be overwhelming. Old methods and old ways of teaching, for example, may not be relevant any more. It is an IT world, yet many schools, I observe, are still mainly using the blackboard, the duster and chalk. The classroom need not be square, with tables and chairs all facing the same

Column: 1308

direction towards the blackboard. We should use more IT in the schools and in teaching. This will make learning more fun. And how do we impart good moral values or highlight character development when students and schools are bent and preoccupied with examination grades. Examination grades are important, but not everything.

    Are we bogging down our students with too many facts and figures that they do not have the time to think for themselves? Is it stifling initiative and creativity? Are we producing a generation that is averse to risk-taking, that is so kiasu? This is a pertinent question as Singapore enters a new phase of development in the new economy, which beckons us with opportunities and challenges of risk-taking, of entrepreneurship, of going global, and of daring to do. But is our education system preparing our young to take on these challenges in the new economy?

    Are they taught the right skills in our schools? Are our young well prepared for life in the outside world? Are they street-wise? Are they equipped and ready to take on or deal with businessmen from China, Hong Kong, Korea or Japan?

    Society as a whole should also be more tolerant of those who dared to try but failed. There should be no stigma in failure. Remember, failure is the mother of success. This climate of support will then encourage more to strike out, take risk and be entrepreneurial.

    Sir, education should also include the training and retraining of our working adults. It saddens me to see workers in their 40s in my meet-the-people sessions, who are retrenched in the economic restructuring, who could not find new jobs easily, as they have no new or relevant skills. Some are still looking for canteen stalls, security jobs, cleaning jobs, and such like, when the economy has changed radically. Many are fast becoming unemployable.

    We should therefore do more for this group of workers, and retrain them for the new economy. We have apprenticeship training scheme for the young, why not

Column: 1309

more apprenticeship training scheme for the older workers. If necessary, pay them a subsistence allowance when they are under intensive training, as they have families to support. We should therefore allocate more grants from our budget surplus for adult retraining, and make it a people's movement for skills upgrading.

    Sir, while we go global, many of our graduates have to go overseas to work, we must remain rooted in Singapore. We must anchor every Singaporean to our own homeland. But how do we cultivate this sense of belonging and bonding, when our schools do not give much emphasis to our own history and culture?

    History lessons are downplayed or not given much attention in schools. Whereas in the United States, every child in school knows about George Washington, Abraham Lincoln, John Kennedy, or the American War of Independence. We must therefore give more thought and priority to the teaching of history in our schools.

    Sir, on that note, I support the motion standing in the name of the Minister for Finance.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, in his first Budget Statement for the millennium, the Finance Minister said that we could expect to get back soon to the pre-crisis growth rate. We can expect measures designed to help businesses tide over the crisis will not be extended and Government charges will be increased very soon.

    The property tax rebate of 55% is now reduced to 25%. The Ministry of National Development has also announced increases in the development charges. With the increases, will we once again face the pre-crisis situation of asset inflation? Will the rent plus other increases cause the cost of business to rise and our competitiveness to be depleted? We can rejoice that we are out of the economic difficulty and can expect better prospects in the new millennium. But what kind of a reward do those people who have made sacrifices get? The Government announced that it would top up their CPF by $250. Is this meagre

Column: 1310

amount of $250 the only reward that they are getting? Those who have not contributed to CPF also made sacrifices but they do not even get a single cent.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, in 1998 when we faced the regional economic crisis, the Government announced a $10 billion cost-cutting package. But the thrust of cost-cutting was on the workers, through the 10% CPF cut and the 5% pay cut. So through the sacrifices of the workers, the Government was able to cut down the cost by $7 billion. In 1999, the Government announced a budget deficit of $5.1 billion. This was played up in the media as if the Government was also affected very greatly by the crisis in order to justify that requiring workers to cut their pay and to make sacrifices are reasonable.

    In the Budget debate in 1999, I said that the deficit was not a true deficit but was a result of large increase in development estimates. The Minister for Finance just announced that there is now a surplus of $3.2 billion instead of a deficit. This was because the development expenditure estimated in the 1999 budget was not used up. The Government has the responsibility to explain to the people whether the 1999 budget was one with a political motive to persuade the people to make sacrifices.

    In 1999, many businessmen faced losses, some factories even had to close down. Many Singaporeans had to tighten their purse strings and their belts because of a pay cut, CPF cut, and unemployment. But the Government was not affected. There was no deficit - it was played up at that time. Instead, there is now a surplus. No wonder when the economy was still recovering, the Government could not wait even a moment in taking the opportunity to announce in November 1999 the restoration of the pay cut for civil servants, including the Ministers' pay. Otherwise, the surplus would be more than $3.2 billion. The Government has forgotten that in 1999 they wanted workers to have their pay cut to pull through the economic crisis together. The workers' pay has not been restored to the previous level. The 10% CPF cut in

Column: 1311

employer's contribution will only be restored by 2%. But the Government took the lead in pay increases for themselves, and enjoyed the fruits of economic recovery, while the people in general were still suffering from the impact of the crisis. The people were hoping that better time would come in the form of bonuses. But the Government has beaten them to it by taking the chunk of the fruit of the economic recovery with the withdrawal of the 10% tax rebate. So when times are bad, the Government's policy is to first require workers to make sacrifices by reducing workers' wages but when times are good, the Government took care of its own pocket. This is the true colour of the PAP Government.

    In this Budget, the Government has even announced that the water tariffs will be increased and the water borne fee will be increased by 100%. All the utilities charges will also be increased as a result. It will add to the burden of the people.

    Mr Noris Ong and Mr Leong Horn Kee have suggested allowing group offsetting of losses to help ease the cash flow of companies undertaking new ventures which are loss-making.     A company sets up a subsidiary as a separate legal entity to carry out a particular activity because it wants to limit its liabilities and exposure arising from that activity. Since a subsidiary is a separate entity which can sue or be sued in its own right, there is no fundamental reason to treat it differently for tax

Column: 1393

    Allowing group relief represents a fundamental change to our corporate tax regime and can have significant revenue implications. If group relief were allowed, profitable companies within a group may end up not having to pay tax on their profits if losses incurred by other companies within the group were included. This may open up opportunities for tax planning. It will raise the cost of tax administration because complex tax rules will need to be drawn up to prevent abuse, and has invariably been the experience of countries which allow group relief.

    One point which Members may not be aware of is that currently, we allow losses to be carried forward indefinitely. Hence, as long as a company can turn around, the earlier losses can be used to offset tax on the later profits.

    As for foreign losses incurred by our companies setting up operations abroad, just as their foreign income is not taxed unless remitted to Singapore, likewise, their foreign losses should not be allowed for offset against domestic income. Otherwise, Government will end up subsidising foreign ventures from domestic tax revenue. As a concession, the Overseas Investment Incentive allows capital losses from the sale of shares in, or liquidation of, approved overseas investments to be set off against the company's Singapore-sourced income.
